name: df-subc
params: setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5, setvar s6, setvar s7
body: |- wceq(csubc, cmpt(s0, ccat, cab(s1, wa(wbr(cv(s1), cssc, cfv(chomf, cv(s0))), wsbc(s2, cdm(cdm(cv(s1))), wral(s3, cv(s2), wa(wcel(cfv(cfv(ccid, cv(s0)), cv(s3)), co(cv(s3), cv(s1), cv(s3))), wral(s4, cv(s2), wral(s5, cv(s2), wral(s6, co(cv(s3), cv(s1), cv(s4)), wral(s7, co(cv(s4), cv(s1), cv(s5)), wcel(co(cv(s7), co(cop(cv(s3), cv(s4)), cfv(cco, cv(s0)), cv(s5)), cv(s6)), co(cv(s3), cv(s1), cv(s5))))))))))))))
comment: ` ( Subcat `` C ) ` is the set of all the subcategory specifications of the category ` C ` . Like ~ df-subg , this is not actually a collection of categories (as in definition 4.1(a) of [Adamek] p. 48), but only sets which when given operations from the base category (using ~ df-resc ) form a category. All the objects and all the morphisms of the subcategory belong to the supercategory. The identity of an object, the domain and the codomain of a morphism are the same in the subcategory and the supercategory. The composition of the subcategory is a restriction of the composition of the supercategory. (Contributed by FL, 17-Sep-2009.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 4-Jan-2017.)
